article.description: The Hawks had too many guards for Wake Forest to, well, guard as they moved among the Elite.

images.name: West Delonte 040325 195x262
images.caption: Delonte West had 24 points, but Pat Carroll's clutch 3s were just as big for St. Joe's.

related.description: Jameer Nelson and Delonte West combined for 48 points, but St. Joe's "other" guards kept the Hawks soaring.
related.title: Two too many guards to guard
related.headline: Two too many guards to guard

article.headline: Nelson, West help Hawks finish Wake
article.linkText: Wake and bake: Saint Joe's marches on

inlines.body:
Dick Vitale's Tourney Take
The name is Martelli -- he's Italian, he's bald and his Saint Joseph's team is in the Elite Eight. The backcourt of Jameer Nelson and Delonte West (24 points each) came through for coach Phil Martelli on Thursday night. West hit all six of his free throws, including two to ice the game in the closing seconds. I said before the game that St. Joe's would need to hit at least 10 3-pointers to win (the Hawks were 12-of-24). The Hawks also did a great job defensively on point guard Chris Paul, who scored just 12 points (2-of-6 from the field). Give reserve Tyrone Barley lots of credit for that defensive effort. And wing Pat Carroll was 5-of-7 on trifectas (17 points overall).
More on Thursday's Games

article.story: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) -- Tyrone Barley lived up to his label as Saint Joseph's defensive stopper. He proved he's an offensive threat, too. Barley harassed and hounded Wake Forest point guard Chris Paul into one of his worst games of the season and scored 13 points in Saint Joseph's 84-80 victory Thursday night. Barley, often lost in the mix behind the dynamic backcourt of Jameer Nelson and Delonte West, was a big reason why the Hawks advanced to the regional final for the first time since 1981. "I take so much pride in my defense," Barley said. "But when you have two great guards and the defense if focusing all their attention on them, it's so much easier for us to find a shot." Barley was needed most out on the perimeter in the second half when St. Joe's big men ran into foul trouble. John Bryant and Dwayne Jones each picked up four fouls early in the second half, forcing the Hawks to play small. That was no problem for Barley, the 6-foot-1 bundle of energy off the bench. With the Demon Deacons started dumping the ball inside, Barley coolly hit a 3 to stretch the lead to five. Then Barley would give the Hawks an 11-point lead when he was left alone at the top of the arc to sink another 3-pointer with 6:41 left. "I wanted to speed up the tempo,'' said Barley, who played 34 minutes. "I wanted to get them going." Barley, though, earned his niche this year defensively and he completely handcuffed Paul, the ACC freshman of the year. Paul took only four shots in the first half and went almost 14 minutes without a basket. Paul finished with 12 points, though seven points came on free throws. "There are so many teams that played us this year where there was a defensive specialist whose job it was to try and limit my touches and make me have tough trips up the court. He did a good job tonight," Paul said. Barley and coach Phil Martelli had a cram session this week on Paul, the skinny freshman point guard with the quick first step, innate passing sense and solid jump shot. Barley said he noticed a flaw -- Paul went almost entirely to his right. "I was basically playing him to his left and he wasn't trying to be aggressive," Barley said. "I wanted to concentrate on not letting him score." Barley and Nelson, St. Joe's only two seniors, go one-on-one in practice, and Martelli has credited Barley with making Nelson into a better player with his stout defense. The duo have won more games than any senior class in Saint Joseph's history. Martelli, though, said Barley could make more of a contribution if he worked on his jumper. So Barley would go into Alumni Fieldhouse, often alone, and shot until his arms became heavy and tired. In the first half, Barley woke up the Hawks' slow-starting offense. Saint Joe's trailed by nine early in game, but Barley hit a 3-pointer to pull the Hawks within three, then hit another that got them within one. "I could have been out partying, but I was in the gym," Barley said. "It lets me know it paid off."
